page.title: Fair Stood the Wind for France

revision.comment: Link to DAB page -> redlink. Quotes for a poem
revision.text:
{{infobox book | | name = Fair Stood the Wind for France | image = Image:FairStoodTheWindFor France.jpg | caption = First US edition | author = [[H. E. Bates]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = Nicholas Panesis | country = United Kingdom | language = English | series = | genre = | publisher = [[Michael Joseph (publisher)|Michael Joseph]] (UK)
[[Little Brown]] (US) | release_date = 1944 | media_type = Print | pages = | oclc = 220638129 | preceded_by = ''How Sleep the Brave'' (1943) | followed_by = ''[[The Cruise of the Breadwinner]]'' (1946) }} '''''Fair Stood the Wind for France''''' is a novel written by English author [[H. E. Bates]]. The novel was first published in 1944 and was Bates's first financial success. The title comes from the first line of "[[Agincourt (poem)|Agincourt]]", a poem by [[Michael Drayton]] (1563–1631).[http://www.megaessays.com/viewpaper/42557.html Fair Stood the Wind for France Book Review essays] ==Plot introduction== The story concerns John Franklin, the pilot of a [[Wellington bomber]], who badly injures his arm when he crash-lands the aircraft in German-[[occupied France]] during the [[World War II|Second World War]]. He and his crew make their way to an isolated farmhouse and are taken in by the family of a French farmer. Plans are made to smuggle them all back to Britain via [[Vichy France|Vichy]]-controlled [[Marseille]] but Franklin's conditions worsens and he remains at the farm during the hot summer weeks that follow and falls in love with the farmer's daughter Françoise. Eventually they make the hazardous journey together by rowing boat, bicycle and train. ==Adaptations== The book was adapted into a 4-part television mini-series in 1980 for the [[BBC]], starring [[David Beames]] as Franklin and [[Cécile Paoli]] as Françoise.{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0397786/ |title= Fair Stood the Wind for France (1980) |publisher=IMDb |accessdate=2009-11-15}} This production is available on DVD, distributed by [[Acorn Media UK]]. In November 2009, [[BBC Radio 4]] broadcast a two part dramatisation by Maddy Fredericks in the Classic Serial strand.{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00nsgvw |title=Classic Serial: Fair Stood The Wind For France |work=BBC Radio 4 Programmes |publisher=BBC |accessdate=2009-11-15}} ==Publication history== * 1944, UK, Michael Joseph, Hardback * 1944, US, Little, Brown and Co., Hardback * 1958, UK, Penguin, Paperback * 1970, UK, Penguin, {{ISBN|0-14-001279-6}}, Paperback * 1971, UK, Prentice-Hall, {{ISBN|0-582-23330-5}}, Paperback * 1983, UK, Chivers, {{ISBN|0-8511-9242-4}}, Large print * 1987, UK, Chivers, {{ISBN|0-7451-5779-3}}, Audio cassette, read by [[Nigel Havers]] * 1987, US, G K Hall, {{ISBN|0-8161-9667-2}}, Audio cassette * 1999, US, Blackstone, {{ISBN|0-7861-1494-0}}, Audio cassette * 1999, US, Blackstone, {{ISBN|0-7861-9935-0}}, Compact disc * 2005, UK, Penguin, {{ISBN|0-14-118816-2}}, Pub date 07 Apr 2005, Paperback * 2005, US, Thorndike, {{ISBN|0-7862-7218-X}}, Pub date 3 May 2005, Large print (p/b) * 2005, US, Kessinger, various, on demand == References == ==External links== * {{BBC programme}} * {{IMDb title|id=0397786|title=Fair Stood the Wind for France}} {{H. E. Bates}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fair Stood The Wind For France}} [[Category:1944 British novels]] [[Category:English novels]] [[Category:World War II novels]] [[Category:Novels by H. E. Bates]] [[Category:Little, Brown and Company books]] [[Category:Novels set in France]] [[Category:Aviation novels]] {{Europe-novel-stub}} {{1940s-novel-stub}} {{WWII-novel-stub}}

{{Infobox summit | summit_name = Global Irish Economic Forum | other_titles = | image = Global Irish Economic Forum 2009 logo.jpg | caption = Official logo of the conference | country = | venues = | cities = [[Farmleigh]], [[Phoenix Park]], [[Dublin]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] | date = 18–20 September 2009 | participants = Various Irish and international figures from the worlds of business and culture | founder = [[David McWilliams (economics pundit)|David McWilliams]] | precedes = | follows = | website = }} The '''Global Irish Economic Forum''' is a biennial conference held in [[Dublin]], [[Ireland]]. Inspired by the [[World Economic Forum]] in [[Switzerland]],<ref name="Global Irish Economic Summit planned for Farmleigh">{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/breaking-news/ireland/global-irish-economic-summit-planned-for-farmleigh-14476070.html|title=Global Irish Economic Summit planned for Farmleigh|date=2009-09-01|accessdate=2009-09-18|publisher=''[[The Belfast Telegraph]]''}}</ref> international figures from the worlds of business and culture attend the event. The first Forum was held at [[Farmleigh]] in [[Dublin]]'s [[Phoenix Park]] from 18–20 September 2009, and was given widespread coverage by [[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]].<ref name="Forum Coverage">{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/features/economicforum/rtecoverage.html |title=Forum Coverage |accessdate=2009-09-18 |publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090922195506/http://www.rte.ie/news/features/economicforum/rtecoverage.html |archivedate=22 September 2009 }}</ref> The second forum was held at [[Dublin Castle]] in 2011.
== Background == The idea for the Forum was conceived by economist [[David McWilliams (economics pundit)|David McWilliams]] who then informed the Irish Government.<ref name="Martin sparks turf war with Coughlan over economy forum"/><ref name="180 leading figures to attend think-in"/><ref name="Diaspora gathering details unveiled"/> The hosting of the event caused a political disagreement between Irish [[Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade|Minister for Foreign Affairs]] [[Micheál Martin]] and [[Tánaiste]] and [[Minister for Jobs, Enterprise and Innovation|Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment]] [[Mary Coughlan (politician)|Mary Coughlan]].<ref name="Martin sparks turf war with Coughlan over economy forum">{{cite web|author=Sam Smyth|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/martin-sparks-turf-war-with-coughlan-over-economy-forum-1875200.html|title=Martin sparks turf war with Coughlan over economy forum|date=2009-09-02|accessdate=2009-09-18|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}}</ref> The [[Department of Jobs, Enterprise and Innovation|Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment]] sought successful members of the [[Irish diaspora]], with [[Taoiseach]] [[Brian Cowen]] personally inviting them to attend the event in April.<ref name="Martin sparks turf war with Coughlan over economy forum"/><ref name="180 leading figures to attend think-in"/> However, Martin claimed that the "global Irish family" was his department's responsibility.<ref name="Martin sparks turf war with Coughlan over economy forum"/> Martin launched the event on the afternoon of 1 September 2009.<ref name="Economic summit for Ireland details to be released">{{cite web|url=http://www.examiner.ie/breakingnews/business/economic-summit-for-ireland-details-to-be-released-424609.html|title=Economic summit for Ireland details to be released|date=2009-09-01|accessdate=2009-09-18|publisher=''[[Irish Examiner]]''}}</ref>
== Guests == Guests pay their own expenses.<ref name="180 leading figures to attend think-in"/><ref name="Diaspora gathering details unveiled"/><ref name="Farmleigh event to seek diaspora ideas">{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0901/forum-business.html|title=Farmleigh event to seek diaspora ideas|date=2009-09-01|accessdate=2009-09-18|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]}}</ref> Attendees have come from [[Argentina]], [[Australia]], [[United Kingdom|Britain]], [[People's Republic of China|China]], [[Europe]], the [[Middle East]] and [[New Zealand]].<ref name="180 leading figures to attend think-in">{{cite web|author=Brian O'Mahony|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/sport/180-leading-figures-to-attend-think-in-99959.html|title=180 leading figures to attend think-in|date=2009-09-02|accessdate=2009-09-18|publisher=''[[Irish Examiner]]''}}</ref> [[Michael O'Leary (Ryanair)|Michael O'Leary]] was notably absent because of his lack of popularity with the Irish Government.<ref name="Government rallies Irish diaspora to help deliver the 'smart economy'"/> In alphabetical order, notable guests with international connections include:
* [[Craig Barrett (businessman)|Craig Barrett]], former CEO of [[Intel Corporation]]<ref name="Global Irish Economic Summit planned for Farmleigh"/><ref name="Martin sparks turf war with Coughlan over economy forum"/><ref name="180 leading figures to attend think-in"/><ref name="Diaspora gathering details unveiled"/><ref name="Farmleigh event to seek diaspora ideas"/> * [[Loretta Brennan-Glucksman]], chairperson of [[The American Ireland Fund]]<ref name="Martin sparks turf war with Coughlan over economy forum"/><ref name="180 leading figures to attend think-in"/><ref name="Diaspora gathering details unveiled"/> * [[John Collison]], Limerick-born entrepreneur * [[Kip Condron]], CEO of [[AXA Financial]]<ref name="180 leading figures to attend think-in"/><ref name="Farmleigh event to seek diaspora ideas"/> * Tom Corcoran, senior adviser with the [[Carlyle Group]]<ref name="Experts agree banks must be stabilised before the recovery"/> * [[Dermot Desmond]], financier,<ref name="Government rallies Irish diaspora to help deliver the 'smart economy'"/> entrepreneur and major shareholder of [[Celtic F.C.]].<ref name="Emigrants returning for think-tank">{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ukpress/article/ALeqM5iI-w4QpPc12fyRMnjY4gZGAdEGUA|title=Emigrants returning for think-tank|date=2009-09-01|accessdate=2009-09-18|publisher=[[Press Association]]}}</ref> * [[Moya Doherty]], producer of [[Riverdance]] and director of [[Tyrone Productions]]<ref name="Martin sparks turf war with Coughlan over economy forum"/><ref name="180 leading figures to attend think-in"/> * [[Irial Finan]], [[The Coca-Cola Company|Coca-Cola]]<ref name="Government rallies Irish diaspora to help deliver the 'smart economy'"/> * John Fitzpatrick, chief executive of [[Fitzpatrick Hotel Group]] * [[Bob Geldof]], political activist and former rock star<ref name="Global Irish Economic Summit planned for Farmleigh"/><ref name="Martin sparks turf war with Coughlan over economy forum"/><ref name="180 leading figures to attend think-in"/><ref name="Diaspora gathering details unveiled"/><ref name="Farmleigh event to seek diaspora ideas"/><ref name="Government rallies Irish diaspora to help deliver the 'smart economy'"/> * [[Basil Geoghegan]], managing director of [[Deutsche Bank]] in [[London]]<ref name="Government rallies Irish diaspora to help deliver the 'smart economy'"/> * [[James Hogan (executive)|James Hogan]], CEO of [[Etihad Airways]]<ref name="Martin sparks turf war with Coughlan over economy forum"/> * [[PJ Hough]], corporate vice president of [[Microsoft]] * [[Neil Jordan]], [[Academy Award]]-winning film director<ref name="Forum: 'good ideas on the table'"/> * [[Alan Joyce (executive)|Alan Joyce]], CEO of [[Qantas]]<ref name="Global Irish Economic Summit planned for Farmleigh"/><ref name="Martin sparks turf war with Coughlan over economy forum"/><ref name="Diaspora gathering details unveiled"/><ref name="Farmleigh event to seek diaspora ideas"/> * [[Declan Kelly (businessperson)|Declan Kelly]], director of [[American Ireland Fund]] * [[Gerald Lawless]], [[Jumeirah (hotel chain)|Jumeirah group]]<ref name="Martin sparks turf war with Coughlan over economy forum"/> * [[Myles Lee]], [[CRH plc]]<ref name="Government rallies Irish diaspora to help deliver the 'smart economy'"/> * [[Pearse Lyons]], founder and president of [[Alltech]] of [[Nicholasville, Kentucky]], USA, which is the name sponsor of [[Muhammad Ali]]'s charity in [[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville]]<ref name="Ali thanks people of Ennis for warm reception">{{cite web|author=Ronan McGreevey|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2009/0919/1224254865830.html|title=Ali thanks people of Ennis for warm reception|date=2009-09-19|accessdate=2009-09-19|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''|quote=The letter is written by Ali’s friend John Ramsey, who is involved with the Alltech Muhammad Ali Centre Global Education and Charitable Fund based in Louisville, Kentucky. It was also sent to Alltech’s founder and president Dr Pearse Lyons who organised Ali’s visit to Ireland, and was one of the guests yesterday at the economic forum of the global Irish in Farmleigh House. Irish-owned Alltech is based in Ali’s home state of Kentucky.}}</ref> * [[Robert J. "Bob" McCann|Bob McCann]], former head of [[Merrill Lynch]]'s brokerage business<ref name="Experts agree banks must be stabilised before the recovery"/> * [[Stan McCarthy]], [[Kerry Group]]<ref name="Government rallies Irish diaspora to help deliver the 'smart economy'"/> * [[Brendan McDonagh]], CEO of [[HSBC Bank USA|HSBC North America]]<ref name="Martin sparks turf war with Coughlan over economy forum"/> * [[Paul McGuinness]], manager of [[U2]] * [[Denis O'Brien]], chairman of [[Digicel]] * [[Liam O'Mahony]], chairman of [[Smurfit Kappa]]<ref name="Government rallies Irish diaspora to help deliver the 'smart economy'"/> * [[Gerry Robinson]], former chairman of [[Allied Domecq]] and former chairperson and CEO of [[Granada plc|Granada]]<ref name="Experts agree banks must be stabilised before the recovery"/> * [[Dan Rooney]], [[United States Ambassador to Ireland]]<ref name="Martin sparks turf war with Coughlan over economy forum"/><ref name="180 leading figures to attend think-in"/> * [[Anita Sands]], managing director of [[Citigroup]] in [[New York City]]<ref name="Government rallies Irish diaspora to help deliver the 'smart economy'"/> * [[Peter Sutherland]], former [[Attorney General of Ireland]]<ref name="Government rallies Irish diaspora to help deliver the 'smart economy'"/> * [[Denis Swanson]], president of the [[Fox Broadcasting Company]]<ref name="Martin sparks turf war with Coughlan over economy forum"/><ref name="180 leading figures to attend think-in"/><ref name="Diaspora gathering details unveiled"/><ref name="Farmleigh event to seek diaspora ideas"/> * [[Margaret Sweeney (businesswoman)|Margaret Sweeney]], CEO of [[An Post#Postbank|Postbank]]<ref name="Government rallies Irish diaspora to help deliver the 'smart economy'"/> * [[Willie Walsh (Irish businessman)|Willie Walsh]], [[British Airways]]<ref name="Government rallies Irish diaspora to help deliver the 'smart economy'"/>
== 2009 Forum ==
=== Events === Taoiseach Brian Cowen gave the opening address,<ref name="Farmleigh event to seek diaspora ideas"/> talking about the concept of a smart economy.<ref name="Diaspora gathering details unveiled"/> A panel discussion then took place on the topic of "the global economy: positioning Ireland for the upturn" and this was followed by further panel discussions on "Ireland—the innovation island", "promoting brand Ireland through our global cultural profile", "Ireland’s image abroad: what is it now, how can it be improved and what role can new media play" and "Ireland and its Diaspora: harnessing unique resource".<ref name="Diaspora gathering details unveiled"/>
Those attending also visited [[Áras an Uachtaráin]] for a meeting with [[President of Ireland]] [[Mary McAleese]] and Mary Coughlan presented a meal at [[Dublin Castle]].<ref name="Martin sparks turf war with Coughlan over economy forum"/><ref name="Diaspora gathering details unveiled"/><ref name="President praises delegates' efforts"/>
Guests will also attend the [[2009 All-Ireland Senior Football Championship Final|All-Ireland Senior Football Championship Final]] at [[Croke Park]] on 20 September.<ref name="Diaspora gathering details unveiled"/><ref name="Government rallies Irish diaspora to help deliver the 'smart economy'">{{cite web|author=John Mulligan|url=http://www.independent.ie/business/irish/government-rallies-irish-diaspora-to-help-deliver-the-smart-economy-1870835.html|title=Government rallies Irish diaspora to help deliver the 'smart economy'|date=2009-08-26|accessdate=2009-09-18|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}}</ref> Micheál Martin, whose constituency is [[Cork South-Central (Dáil constituency)|Cork South-Central]], described it as "a piece of opportunistic planning by yours truly in anticipation that [[Cork GAA|Cork]] would reach the final".<ref name="Diaspora gathering details unveiled">{{cite web|author=Laura Slattery|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2009/0901/breaking56.htm|title=Diaspora gathering details unveiled|date=2009-09-01|accessdate=2009-09-18|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''|quote=The Taoiseach will be the only keynote speaker at the event, which opens on Friday the 18th with his address on the so-called smart economy. This will be followed by a panel discussion on “the global economy: positioning Ireland for the upturn”. Other panel discussions include “Ireland - the innovation island”; “promoting brand Ireland through our global cultural profile”; “Ireland’s image abroad: what is it now, how can it be improved and what role can new media play”; and “Ireland and its Diaspora: harnessing unique resource”. The programme also includes a reception hosted by President McAleese at Áras an Uachtaráin, a dinner at Dublin Castle hosted by the Tánaiste, Mary Coughlan, and attendance at the All-Ireland football final at Croke Park. “That was a piece of opportunistic planning by yours truly in anticipation that Cork would reach the final,” Mr Martin said.}}</ref>
=== Controversies === Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment Mary Coughlan was ridiculed in the Irish media after crediting [[Albert Einstein]] for [[Charles Darwin]]'s [[theory of evolution]].<ref name="Coughlan's no Einstein after gaffe at 'smart economy' launch"/> At the launch on 17 September, she made the comparison "like Einstein explaining his theory of evolution".<ref name="Coughlan's no Einstein after gaffe at 'smart economy' launch">{{cite web|author=Senan Molony|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/coughlans-no-einstein-after-gaffe-at-smart-economy-launch-1890227.html|title=Coughlan's no Einstein after gaffe at 'smart economy' launch|date=2009-09-18|accessdate=2009-09-18|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}}</ref> The incident prompted comparisons with American politicians such as [[Dan Quayle]] and [[Sarah Palin]], with the ''[[Evening Herald]]'' referring to Coughlan in a derogatory manner as a "lovely girl" and saying she was "Ireland's own version" of Palin.<ref name="Coughlan reveals she's no Einstein">{{cite web|author=Kevin Doyle, POLITICAL REPORTER |url=http://www.herald.ie/national-news/coughlan--reveals-shes-no-einstein-1890624.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130218052244/http://www.herald.ie/national-news/coughlan--reveals-shes-no-einstein-1890624.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-02-18 |title=Coughlan reveals she's no Einstein |date=2009-09-18 |accessdate=2009-09-18 |publisher=''[[Evening Herald]]'' }}</ref><ref name="After mixing up Darwin and Einstein, how long can we carry on with our laughing stock Tanaiste?">{{cite web|url=http://www.herald.ie/opinion/calamity-coughlan-1890592.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130217200631/http://www.herald.ie/opinion/calamity-coughlan-1890592.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-02-17 |title=After mixing up Darwin and Einstein, how long can we carry on with our laughing stock Tanaiste? |date=2009-09-18 |accessdate=2009-09-18 |publisher=''[[Evening Herald]]'' }}</ref> The error came in the same week as she referred to her [[Green Party (Ireland)|Green Party]] coalition partners as "the vegetables" during an [[Irish language]] radio interview.<ref name="Coughlan's no Einstein after gaffe at 'smart economy' launch"/>
In an interview with [[Bloomberg Television]] at the Forum, shareholder [[Denis O'Brien]] said [[Independent News & Media]] might shut down its flagship [[London]] newspaper ''[[The Independent]]'' by the end of 2009,<ref name="O'Brien sees London's Independent closed by Dec">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/rbssTechMediaTelecomNews/idUSLI32052720090918|title=O'Brien sees London's Independent closed by Dec|date=2009-09-18|accessdate=2009-09-18|publisher=[[Reuters]] | first=Andras | last=Gergely}}</ref> saying it was "irrelevant" and that nobody wanted to read it.<ref name="O'Brien claims 'irrelevant' Independent to fold by Christmas">{{cite web|author=Victoria Thomson|url=http://business.scotsman.com/medialeisure/O39Brien-claims-39irrelevant39-Independent-.5661729.jp|title=O'Brien claims 'irrelevant' Independent to fold by Christmas|date=2009-09-19|accessdate=2009-09-19|publisher=''[[The Scotsman]]''}}</ref> O'Brien also advocated a Yes vote during the [[Twenty-eighth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|second Irish referendum]] on the [[Treaty of Lisbon]], claiming it was "essential for setting Ireland on the path to growth".<ref name="Schools bigger problem than banking’"/>
Craig Barrett, former CEO and chairman of [[Intel Corporation]], warned delegates that Ireland was spending "far too little" on education and that "schools are a bigger problem than banking".<ref name="Schools bigger problem than banking’"/> Taoiseach Brian Cowen seemed to agree with Barrett.<ref name="Schools bigger problem than banking’">{{cite web|author=Brian O’Mahony and Stephen Rogers|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/home/schools-bigger-problem-than-banking-101323.html|title=Schools bigger problem than banking’|date=2009-09-19|accessdate=2009-09-19|publisher=''[[Irish Examiner]]''}}</ref>
Bob Geldof said countries of a similar size to Ireland, some impoverished, were spending as much as 6 per cent on [[research and development]] but that Ireland spends just 2 per cent.<ref name="Schools bigger problem than banking’"/> He also said Mary Coughlan had "a lovely pair of legs" which caused her to blush.<ref name="When Geldof told Mary that she had lovely legs, she should have used them to run a mile">{{cite web|author=Colette Fitzpatrick |url=http://www.herald.ie/opinion/when-geldof-told-mary-that-she-had-lovely-legs-she-should-have-used-them-to-run-a-mile-1896792.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130220223315/http://www.herald.ie/opinion/when-geldof-told-mary-that-she-had-lovely-legs-she-should-have-used-them-to-run-a-mile-1896792.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-02-20 |title=When Geldof told Mary that she had lovely legs, she should have used them to run a mile |date=2009-09-25 |accessdate=2009-09-25 |publisher=''[[Evening Herald]]'' }}</ref>
On the second day of the forum, Irish [[Minister for Arts, Heritage and the Gaeltacht|Minister for Arts, Sport and Tourism]] [[Martin Cullen]] expressed his disagreement with proposed cuts in public sending which were suggested by the McCarthy Report.<ref name="Forum: 'good ideas on the table'">{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0919/forum-business.html|title=Forum: 'good ideas on the table'|date=2009-09-19|accessdate=2009-09-19|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]}}</ref><ref name="Cullen criticises cuts proposals"/> [[Neil Jordan]] said Ireland's culture had not disappointed the country in the same way as institutions such as the banks and the Church had done so.<ref name="Forum: 'good ideas on the table'"/><ref name="Cullen criticises cuts proposals"/> [[Denis O'Brien]] said Ireland's culture was the key to success, saying his [[Digicell]] group obtained a [[Samoa]]n licence because the [[Prime Minister of Samoa|Prime Minister]]'s education had come from Irish priests: "We are famous for our writers, our artists, our poets and we are not famous for much else".<ref name="Cullen criticises cuts proposals">{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2009/0919/breaking36.htm|title=Cullen criticises cuts proposals|date=2009-09-19|accessdate=2009-09-19|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''|quote=Businessman Denis O'Brien told the forum today Ireland's literary and musical heritage can be used to open business doors around the world and help seal deals in the face of economic crisis. "The fact that we have such a strong culture as a country really gives us one of the big advantages of any nation in the world," he said. "We are famous for our writers, our artists, our poets and we are not famous for much else," said the chairman of Digicel, adding that his cell phone group had got a licence to operate in Samoa because the country's prime minister had been educated by an Irish religious order.}}</ref><ref name="Singing & dancing seen helping Ireland out of crisis">{{cite news|author=Carmel Crimmins|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/mediaNews/idUSLJ46784220090919|title=Singing & dancing seen helping Ireland out of crisis|date=2009-09-19|accessdate=2009-09-19|publisher=[[Reuters]]}}</ref> There was a consensus amongst those attending that Ireland's banks needed to be reformed.<ref name="Experts agree banks must be stabilised before the recovery">{{cite web|author=JOE BRENNAN and JOHN MULLIGAN|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/experts-agree-banks-must-be-stabilised-before-the-recovery-1891232.html|title=Experts agree banks must be stabilised before the recovery|date=2009-09-19|accessdate=2009-09-19|publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''}}</ref> Micheál Martin, in his closing remarks to the Forum, said the contributions of the delegates "will be taken forward and action will be taken", spoke of his hopes to establish an "online portal for a virtual community of people of Irish descent to stay in touch" and stated he would also focus on non-traditional countries of the Irish diaspora such as [[Russia]].<ref name="Martin hails ideas forum input">{{cite web|author=IRISH TIMES REPORTERS|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2009/0919/breaking6.htm|title=Martin hails ideas forum input|date=2009-09-19|accessdate=2009-09-19|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''|quote="Your work this week will be taken forward and action will be taken," Mr Martin told participants at a press conference this evening. "We are going through a crisis at the moment which does require ... a very significant (cut to) budget. They are the overarching priorities that the Government has at the moment and we have to try and work within that." Mr Martin said the Government would look at creating an online portal for a virtual community of people of Irish descent to stay in touch, as well as more educational exchanges and diaspora-linked tourism. He also said he wanted to boost Ireland’s presence around the world to harness the Irish diaspora in countries not traditionally focused on before, such as Russia.}}</ref>
=== Reaction === President Mary McAleese praised the "“interest in and commitment to" of those who attended, saying the event showed that Ireland is "considerably more than an island on the edge of Europe, but the centre of a vast networked community".<ref name="President praises delegates' efforts">{{cite web|author=Steven Carroll|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2009/0919/1224254861498.html|title=President praises delegates' efforts|date=2009-09-19|accessdate=2009-09-19|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''|quote=Ms McAleese said the forum highlighted that Ireland was “considerably more than an island on the edge of Europe, but the centre of a vast networked community”. [...] Speaking at a reception in Áras an Uachtaráin for delegates, Mrs McAleese said, regardless of their ties to the country, the participants’ “interest in and commitment to” Ireland was valued.}}</ref>
Martin Murphy, managing director of [[Hewlett-Packard|Hewlitt-Packard Ireland]], saw it as an opportunity to "truly begin positioning this small, export-driven country for real and sustained economic renewal and growth".<ref name="Shifting the focus to an enterprise culture">{{cite web|author=Martin Murphy|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/opinion/2009/0917/1224254717980.html|title=Shifting the focus to an enterprise culture|date=2009-09-17|accessdate=2009-09-19|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''|quote=This weekend’s Global Economic Forum conference at Farmleigh House in Dublin is a great opportunity for Ireland – and I stress the word “opportunity’’, because I view the forum as an opportunity for business and political leaders to come together to truly begin positioning this small, export-driven country for real and sustained economic renewal and growth.}}</ref>

{{For|other alliances with similar names|Holy League (disambiguation){{!}}Holy League}}
The '''Holy League''' of 1538 was a short-lived alliance of Christian states arranged by [[Pope Paul III]] at the urging of the [[Republic of Venice]].
In 1537 the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] admiral [[Hayreddin Barbarossa]], Pasha of [[Algiers]], had nearly captured the Venetian stronghold of [[Corfu]] and ravaged the coasts of [[Calabria]]. In the face of this threat Pope Paul succeeded in February 1538 in organizing the ''Holy League'' which consisted of the [[Papal States]], the Republic of Venice, the [[Knights Hospitaller|Maltese Knights]] and Spain with her vassal states of [[Kingdom of Naples|Naples]] and [[Kingdom of Sicily|Sicily]].
To confront Barbarossa and his roughly 120 [[galley]]s and [[fusta]]s, the League assembled a fleet of about 300 ships (162 galleys and 140 sailing ships) in September 1538 near Corfu. Its supreme commander was the [[Genoa|Genoese]] admiral [[Andrea Doria]], who was then in the service of Emperor [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles V]].
The two fleets met on 28 September 1538 in the [[Battle of Preveza]], and Barbarossa decisively defeated the numerically superior Christian alliance. Doria's leadership in the battle was less than vigorous and is widely believed to have been a major contributing cause to the League's defeat. His hesitation to bring his own ships into full action (he personally owned a number of them) and to sacrifice them for the good of Venice, the traditional rival of his home town of Genoa, are generally considered to explain his actions at Preveza.
== See also == * [[Ottoman–Venetian War (1537–1540)]] * [[Siege of Castelnuovo]]

Hamilton, "Sea-Wolves of the Mediterranean," John Murrey, 1910. *Norwich, John Julius, "A History of Venice," Vintage, 1982; {{ISBN|0-679-72197-5}} (pbk.)

{{Infobox spaceflight | name = INSAT 3C | image = Insat3c.gif | image_caption = | mission_type = [[Communications satellite|Communications]]
[[Weather satellite|Weather]] | operator = [[INSAT]] | website = [http://www.isro.org/satellites/insat-3c.aspx INSAT 3C] | COSPAR_ID = 2002-002A | SATCAT = 27298 | mission_duration = | spacecraft_bus = [[I-2K]] | manufacturer = [[Indian Space Research Organisation|ISRO]] | dry_mass = {{convert|1210|kg|lb|abbr=on}} | launch_mass = {{convert|2750|kg|lb|abbr=on}} | power = 2.765 kilowatts | launch_date = {{start-date|23 January 2002, 23:46:57|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = [[Ariane 4|Ariane-42L H10-3]] | launch_site = [[Guiana Space Centre|Kourou]] [[ELA-3]] | launch_contractor = [[Arianespace]] | entered_service = | disposal_type = | deactivated = | orbit_epoch = | orbit_reference = [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Geostationary orbit|Geostationary]] | orbit_periapsis = | orbit_apoapsis = | orbit_inclination = 4 degrees | orbit_period = 24 hours | orbit_longitude = 74° East ({{coord|0|+74|display=inline,title}}) | orbit_slot = | apsis = gee | trans_band = | trans_frequency = | trans_bandwidth = | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW = }} '''INSAT-3C''' is a multipurpose [[satellite]] built by [[ISRO]] and launched by [[Arianespace]] in Jan 2002. INSAT-3C is the second satellite of the [[INSAT]]-3 series. All the transponders provide coverage over India. Insat-3C is controlled from the [[Master Control Facility]] at [[Hassan, India|Hassan]] in [[Karnataka]]. It will provide voice, video and digital data services to India and neighboring countries. == Launch == INSAT 3C was launched by the [[Ariane 4]] launch vehicle of [[Arianespace]] at 5:17 am IST from [[Kourou]], [[French Guiana]] in [[South America]]. INSAT-3C was placed into a Geo-synchronous Transfer Orbit (GTO), 21 minutes after the lift-off, in a 3-axis stabilised mode, with a perigee of 570 km and an apogee of 35,920 km and an inclination of 4° with respect to the equator. After 4 maneuvers INSAT-3C has been put in its final three axis stabilised mode on February 1, 2002.The orbit rising maneuvers were carried out in phases by firing the 440 Newton [[Apogee kick motor|Liquid Apogee Motor(LAM)]]. The satellite carried about 1.5 tonne of propellant ([[Monomethylhydrazine|MMH (MonoMethylHydrazine)]] and [[Mixed Oxides of Nitrogen|MON-3 (Mixed Oxides of Nitrogen)]]) for orbit raising operations as well as for station keeping and in-orbit attitude control.INSAT-3C like all of its predecessors in the [[INSAT]] series has a 3-axis body stabilized spacecraft using momentum/reaction wheels earth sensors, sun sensors, inertial reference unit and [[Magnetorquer|magnetic torquers]].It is equipped with unified bi-propellant thrusters. == Payload == INSAT-3C, carrying Fixed Satellite Services (FSS) transponders, Broadcast Satellite Services (BSS) transponders & Mobile Satellite Services (MSS) transponders is intended to continue the service of INSAT-2DT and INSAT-2C which were nearing their end to life besides enhancing and augmenting the INSAT system capacity. * 24 Normal [[C band (IEEE)|C-band]] transponders providing an EIRP of 37 dBW * 6 Extended C-band transponders with EIRP of 37 dBW * 2 [[S-band]] transponders to provide BSS services with 42 dBW EIRP * 1 MSS transponder operating in S-band up-link and C-band downlink == References == http://www.isro.org/satellites/insat-3c.aspx http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/insat-3c.htm http://www.tracksat.com/satellite165.html http://www.sathint.com/insat-3c http://www.lyngsat.com/in3c.html http://goliath.ecnext.com/coms2/gi_0199-1320742/INDIA-SET-TO-LAUNCH-INSAT.html {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} * [http://www.isro.org ISRO website] * [http://www.antrix.gov.in Commercial arm of ISRO] * [http://dst.gov.in/stsysindia/space.htm Deptt. of Space Under Deptt. Of Science & Tech., Government Of India] {{INSAT Satellites}} {{Indian spacecraft}} {{Orbital launches in 2002}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 2002]] [[Category:Communications satellites in geostationary orbit]] [[Category:Satellite television]] [[Category:INSAT satellites]] [[Category:2002 in India]]

[[File:Fourteen ANA women marching during their graduation ceremony.jpg|thumb|Soldiers of the [[Afghan National Army]] marching into their graduation ceremony at the Kabul Military Training Center (KMTC) in 2011.]] The '''Kabul Military Training Centre''' (KMTC) is a basic training centre for the [[Afghan Armed Forces]]. Located about 8 miles to the east on the outskirts of [[Kabul]], it offers basic courses including 16-week basic infantry training.<ref name="globalsecurity1">{{cite web|author=John Pike |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/afghanistan/kabul_kmtc.htm |title=Kabul Military Training Center |publisher=Globalsecurity.org |date= |accessdate=2012-05-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Bhandari |first=Subel |url=http://www.stripes.com/news/are-afghan-security-forces-up-to-the-post-2014-job-1.177284 |title=Are Afghan security forces up to the post-2014 job? - News |publisher=Stripes |date= |accessdate=2012-05-22}}</ref>
Kabul Military Training Center is one of the biggest basic training centers in [[Afghanistan]]. As of April 2008, of the 70,000 Afghans which had entered the [[Afghan National Army]] (ANA), a third had been trained at the KMTC between 2007 and 2008.<ref name="globalsecurity1"/>
==Basic training== The KMTC undertakes basic combat training of new recruits with a 16-week basic training course. Capable of graduating a 615-person battalion every four weeks there are roughly 2,500 soldiers and airmen undertaking training at any one time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Kabul's+Military+training+centre%3A+Canadian+mentors+help+build+the...-a0163738510 |title=Kabul's Military training centre: Canadian mentors help build the Afghan army ... on the double. - Free Online Library |publisher=Thefreelibrary.com |date=2007-01-01 |accessdate=2012-05-22}}</ref>
===Literacy training=== A major focus of the development of the Afghan Armed Forces is on raising the levels of literacy among the troops. In 2009 less than 35% of recruits could pass basic weapon qualification due to low literacy levels. Recruits were unable to properly read instructions in order to maintain or operate complex western supplied rifles and additional components such as optics. As a result, recruits had to undertake at least 64 hours of lessons in basic reading, writing and arithmetic in order to pass Grade 1 and move to their units.
Recruits were also given the option of a further 128 hours to advance to grade 2 to bring their total to 192 hours. To achieve Grade 3 they had to undertake a further 120 hours which gave them 312 hours of literacy training in total.<ref>{{cite web|author=Rajat Kumar Mohindru |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/as-afghanistan-raises-an-army-first-lessons-are-on-how-to-read-write/944600/ |title=As Afghanistan raises an army, first lessons are on how to read, write |publisher=Indian Express |date=2012-05-03 |accessdate=2012-05-22}}</ref>

[[Image:Bakunin Membership Card.jpg|thumb|right|Bakunin's membership card of the ''League of Peace and Freedom'']] The '''Ligue internationale de la paix''' ('''League of Peace and Freedom''') was created after a public opinion campaign against a war between the [[Second French Empire]] and the [[Kingdom of Prussia]] over [[Luxembourg]]. The [[Luxembourg crisis]] was peacefully resolved in 1867 by the [[Treaty of London (1867)|Treaty of London]] but in 1870 the [[Franco-Prussian War]] could not be prevented so the league dissolved and refounded as the 'Société française pour l'arbitrage entre nations' (League of arbitration between the Nations) in the same year. The '''Société française pour l'arbitrage entre nations''' can be seen as a precursor of the [[Permanent Court of Arbitration]], founded with the first [[Hague Peace Conference]] in 1899, and a precursor of the [[League of Nations]], founded with the [[Treaty of Versailles]] in 1919 and followed by the [[United Nations]]. The establishment of the Permanent Court of Arbitration was also set up by the [[Inter-Parliamentary Union]] that Frédéric Passy founded together with [[William Randal Cremer]] in 1889. ==Inaugural Congress== The Inaugural Congress of the '''League of Peace and Freedom''' (French: Ligue internationale de la paix et de la liberte) was originally planned for September 5, 1867 in [[Geneva]].{{cite journal |title=Pacifism in France, 1889-1914: International Peace as a Human Right |author= Sandi E. Cooper |journal=French Historical Studies |volume= 17 |year= 1991 |jstor=286462 }} [[Emile Acollas]] set up the League's Organising Committee, which enlisted the support of [[John Stuart Mill]], [[Élisée Reclus]], and his brother [[Élie Reclus]]. Other notable supporters included contemporary activists, revolutionaries, and intellectuals such as [[Victor Hugo]], [[Giuseppe Garibaldi]], [[Louis Blanc]], [[Edgar Quinet]], [[Jules Favre]], and [[Alexander Herzen]]. Ten thousand people from across Europe signed petitions in support of the congress.[[Mark Leier]]. ''Bakunin: The Creative Passion''. St. Martin's Press: New York, 2006. p. 178. They also counted on the participation of the [[International Workingmen's Association]] (IWMA), inviting the sections of the IWMA and its leaders, including [[Karl Marx]], to attend the Congress. They decided to postpone the opening of the Congress until September 9, so as to enable delegates of the Lausanne Congress of the IWMA (to be held on September 2–8) to take part.
While the balloting was going on, Citizen Marx called attention to the Peace Congress to be held in Geneva. He said: It was desirable that as many delegates as could make it convenient should attend the Peace Congress in their individual capacity; but that it would be injudicious to take part officially as representatives of the International Association. The International Working Men’s Congress was in itself a peace congress, as the union of the working classes of the different countries must ultimately make international wars impossible. If the promoters of the Geneva Peace Congress really understood the question at issue they ought to have joined the International Association. [From ''[[The Bee-Hive (journal)|The Bee-Hive]] Newspaper'' August 17, 1867, reporting on a meeting of the IWMA Central Council.]
The anarchist [[Mikhail Bakunin]] also played a prominent role in the Geneva Conference, and joined the Central Committee.{{cite book|last=Leier|first=Mark|year=2006|pp=200-202|title=[[Bakunin: The Creative Passion]]|publisher=[[Seven Stories Press]]|isbn=978-1-58322-894-4|ref=harv}} The founding conference was attended by 6,000 people. As Bakunin rose to speak:
the cry passed from mouth to mouth: "Bakunin!" [[Garibaldi]], who was in the chair, stood up, advanced a few steps and embraced him. This solemn meeting of two old and tried warriors of the revolution produced an astonishing impression .... Everyone rose and there was a prolonged and enthusiastic clapping of hands[https://web.archive.org/web/20020214212441/http://flag.blackened.net/revolt/rbr/rbr6/bakunin.html Bakunin's idea of revolution & revolutionary organisation] published by [[Workers Solidarity Movement]] in ''Red and Black Revolution'' No.6, Winter 2002.
==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Bibliography== *[http://www.icrc.org/Web/Eng/siteeng0.nsf/html/57JNAW André Durand: ''Gustave Moynier and the peace societies''. In: ''International Review of the Red Cross'', no 314, p. 532–550 (31-10-1996)] [[Category:1867 establishments in Switzerland]] [[Category:Karl Marx]] [[Category:Mikhail Bakunin]] [[Category:Peace organizations]] [[Category:International arbitration courts and tribunals]]

'''Mbaba Mwana Waresa''' is a [[fertility goddess]] of the [[Zulu religion]] of Southern Africa. She rules over [[rainbows]], [[agriculture]], [[harvests]], [[rain]], and [[beer]] and has power over [[water]] and [[earth]]. She taught Her people how to sow and reap and also taught them the art of making beer. It is this act that has made Her one of the more revered goddesses of the Zulu people.
==Description== Mbaba Mwana Waresa lived in the clouds, in a round hut made of rainbow arches. Her people loved this rain goddess, and whenever they heard the telltale sound of Her thunder drum, they knew that She would be pouring much-needed waters from Her heavenly home. She is the daughter of the sky god [[Umvelinqangi]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cuisinenoirmag.com/delicious-life/even-the-spirits-need-a-menu-as-a-zulu-goddess|title=Even the Spirits Need a Menu as a Zulu Goddess - Cuisine Noir Magazine|first=Wanda|last=Hennig|website=www.cuisinenoirmag.com}}</ref>
She is able to shapeshift Her appearance to that of an animal, hence Her other name, "'''Nomkhubulwane'''", which means "She who chooses the state of an animal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://andriesbotha.net/artwork/2006-2010/nomkhubulwane/|title=Nomkhubulwane - Andries Botha - Artworks & Sculpture|website=andriesbotha.net}}</ref>
According to legend, She was unable to find a suitable husband in the heavens, so She scoured the lands of South Africa in search of a mortal husband, and then defied all of the other gods when She fell in love with a mortal man. In order to make sure he loved Her, She tested him by sending a beautiful bride in Her place while She disguised herself as an ugly hag. Her earthly lover was not fooled and recognized her immediately. They married and to this day, they live in her rainbow covered house in the sky.
==Worship== The Zulu call on Her when they need guidance to make an important decision.<ref>{{cite book |title=Magick of the Gods and Goddesses: Invoking the Power of the Ancient Gods |last=Conway |first=D. J. |year=2003 |publisher=The Crossing Press |isbn=1-58091-153-6 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=t6EGdNpbS2IC&pg=PA208&dq=%22Mbaba+Mwana+Waresa%22 |page=208 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Edgar Cayce and the Eternal Feminine |last=Rogers |first=Lynn |year=2004 |publisher=Star Enterprises International |isbn=1-929841-02-7 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=OBDB3g57x-0C&pg=PA22&dq=%22Mbaba+Mwana+Waresa%22 |page=22 }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

part of the set of 740+ outlines listed at [[Portal:Contents/Outlines]].

Further improvements to this outline are on the way ...--> {{See also|Index of Democratic Republic of the Congo-related articles}} {{double image|right|Flag of the Democratic Republic of the Congo.svg|164|Coat of arms of the Democratic Republic of the Congo.svg|128|The [[Flag of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]]|The [[Coat of arms of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]]}} [[Image:LocationDRCongo.svg|thumb|The location of the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]]] [[Image:Un-congo-kinshasa.png|thumb|An enlargeable map of the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]]]
The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to the Democratic Republic of the Congo:
'''[[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]''' – country located in Central Africa. The country is extremely rich in natural resources but political instability, a lack of infrastructure and a culture of corruption have historically limited development, extraction and exploitation efforts. Besides the capital, Kinshasa, the country's other largest cities are both mining communities (Lubumbashi and Mbuji-Mayi) and the country's largest exports are raw minerals.
{{TOC limit|limit=2}}
==General reference== [[Image:Congo Democratic Republic Map.jpg|thumb|An enlargeable relief map of the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]]] * [[International Phonetic Alphabet|Pronunciation]]: {{IPAc-en|ˈ|k|ɒ|ŋ|ɡ|əʊ}} * Common English country names: The [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], [[Congo-Kinshasa]], etc. * Official English country name: The [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Adjectives]]: Congolese, Congo * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Demonym]](s): * [[ISO country codes]]: CD, COD, 180 * [[ISO region codes]]: See [[ISO 3166-2:CD]] * [[Internet]] [[country code top-level domain]]: [[.cd]]
== Geography of the Democratic Republic of the Congo == [[Image:Congo Kinshasa Topography.png|thumb|An enlargeable topographic map of the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]]]
[[Geography of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] * The Democratic Republic of the Congo is: an [[Equatorial country|equatorial]] [[Megadiverse countries|megadiverse]] [[Nation state|country]] * Location: ** [[Eastern Hemisphere]], on the [[Equator]] ** [[Africa]] *** [[Central Africa]] *** [[Middle Africa]] ** [[Time zone]]s: *** [[West Africa Time]] ([[UTC+01]]) *** [[Central Africa Time]] ([[UTC+02]]) ** Extreme points of the Democratic Republic of the Congo *** High: [[Margherita Peak]] {{convert|5109|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} *** Low: [[South Atlantic Ocean]] 0 m ** Land boundaries: 10,730 km ::{{Flag|Angola}} 2,511 km ::{{Flag|Republic of the Congo}} 2,410 km ::{{Flag|Zambia}} 1,930 km ::{{Flag|Central African Republic}} 1,577 km ::{{Flag|Uganda}} 765 km ::{{Flag|South Sudan}} 628 km ::{{Flag|Tanzania}} 459 km ::{{Flag|Burundi}} 233 km ::{{Flag|Rwanda}} 217 km :* Coastline: [[Gulf of Guinea]] 37 km * Population of the Democratic Republic of the Congo: <!-- xxxxx Wikipedia:WikiProject Topic outline/Drafts/Topic outline of the Democratic Republic of the Congo --> * * Area of the Democratic Republic of the Congo: <!-- zzzz Wikipedia:WikiProject Topic outline/Drafts/Topic outline of the Democratic Republic of the Congo--> * [[:commons:Atlas of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|Atlas of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]]
=== Environment of the Democratic Republic of the Congo === [[Image:Democratic Republic of the Congo BMNG.png|thumb|An enlargeable satellite image of the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]]]
* [[Climate of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] * [[List of ecoregions in the Democratic Republic of the Congo|Ecoregions in the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] * [[Renewable energy in the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] * Protected areas of the Democratic Republic of the Congo ** [[List of biosphere reserves in the Democratic Republic of the Congo|Biosphere reserves in the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] * [[Wildlife of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] ** Fauna of the Democratic Republic of the Congo *** [[List of amphibians of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|Amphibians of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] *** [[List of birds of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|Birds of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] *** [[List of mammals of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|Mammals of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] *** [[List of reptiles of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|Reptiles of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]]
==== Natural geographic features of the Democratic Republic of the Congo ====
* [[List of lakes in the Democratic Republic of the Congo|Lakes of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] * Mountains of the Democratic Republic of the Congo ** [[List of volcanoes in the Democratic Republic of the Congo|Volcanoes in the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] * [[List of rivers of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|Rivers of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]] * World Heritage Sites in the Democratic Republic of the Congo: None
=== Regions of the Democratic Republic of the Congo ===

{{more footnotes|date=September 2018}} {{Noble house| | surname = Genus (''gens'') Péc | estate = | coat of arms = | country = [[Kingdom of Hungary]] | titles = | parent house = | founder = [[Lucas I Péc|Lucas I]] | final ruler = | current head = | founding year = 1200s | dissolution = 14th century | nationality =Hungarian | cadet branches =''a, Zala branch''
* [[Ladislaus Nevnai|House of Nevnai]] * [[Nicholas Ludbregi|House of Ludbregi]] * [[Marcali family|House of Marcali]] * [[Berzencei family|House of Berzencei]] * [[Apor Szentgyörgyi|House of Szentgyörgyi]] * [[Kustáni family|House of Kustáni]] * House of Szőlősi ''b, Apponyi branch''
* House of Őri ** [[Apponyi family|House of Apponyi]] ''c, Ibrányi branch''
* [[Ibrányi family|House of Ibrányi]] }} '''Péc''' or '''Pécz''' (also ''Peech'' or ''Pech'') was the name of a ''gens'' (Latin for "clan"; ''nemzetség'' in Hungarian) in the [[Kingdom of Hungary]]. The powerful and illustrious [[Marcali family|Marcali]] and [[Apponyi family|Apponyi]] noble families descended from this kindred. The clan had large-scale possessions in several counties of [[Transdanubia]], in addition to [[Slavonia]] and other parts of the [[Kingdom of Hungary (1000–1301)|Kingdom of Hungary]]. ==History and family tree== ===Zala branch=== The clan originated from [[Sokoró Hills]], in the southern region of [[Győr County]], their ancient clan estates laid in present-day [[Felpéc]] and [[Kajárpéc]].{{sfn|Karácsonyi|1901|p=427}} The earliest known member of the kindred was [[Lucas I Péc|Lucas I]], who lived in the early 13th century. He is apparently the founder of the clan too.{{sfn|Kádár|2018|p=6}} Based on the clan's coat-of-arms (narrow silver stripe in blue shield), it is possible that Lucas was a knight from [[Western Europe]], who arrived to Hungary during the early reign of [[Andrew II of Hungary]]. For his military service, he was granted lands in Győr County and the surrounding regions.{{sfn|Vikár|1995}} Depending on his origin (German or French), Lucas might have come to the country as an accompanist of either [[Gertrude of Merania]] (1205) or [[Yolanda de Courtenay]] (1215), the first and second spouse of Andrew II, respectively. His career and life is difficult to outline: it is presumable that he is identical with that Lucas, who served as [[Master of the cupbearers]] in the royal court from 1229 to 1230.{{sfn|Zsoldos|2011|p=59}} Lucas' eldest son was [[George Péc|George]], who owned [[Ludbreg]] sometimes before 1248. Ludbreg later became a residence of his son Peter, who erected a castle above the village and adopted his surname after his lands' centre. This branch died out with George's grandson [[Nicholas Ludbregi]] in 1357, thereafter Ludbreg and other lands became the property of Ban [[John Csúz]] and his descendants.{{sfn|Engel|1996|p=363}} The most powerful member of the kindred was George's another son [[Denis Péc|Denis]]. Initially, he was a confidant of ''[[junior king|rex iunior]]'' [[Stephen V of Hungary|Stephen]], but later joined the partisans of the elderly [[Béla IV of Hungary]]. He actively participated in the military campaigns against Austria and Bohemia. He served as [[Palatine of Hungary]] and other high-ranking positions several times during the era of feudal anarchy.{{sfn|Kádár|2018|p=11}} His son, [[John Péc|John]] was ''ispán'' of [[Veszprém County (former)|Veszprém County]] as a confidant of Queen Mother [[Tomasina Morosini]] in 1295,{{sfn|Zsoldos|2011|p=227}} while his unidentified daughter married [[Stephen Hahót]]. Through their only son [[Nicholas VII Hahót|Nicholas]], they were ancestors of the powerful Bánfi (Bánffy) de Alsólendva noble family.Engel: ''Genealógia'' (Genus Hahót 1.) George's third son was Serfesd, who owned Nevna (or Névna), present-day [[Levanjska Varoš]] in [[Croatia]]. His only son [[Ladislaus Nevnai]] held estates in Valkó and [[Požega County|Požega]] counties, including [[Orljavac|Orjava]] (today Orljavac, Croatia), and was considered one of the richest landowners of the region.{{sfn|Árvai|2013|p=105}} He fathered two daughters, Catherine and an unidentified girl. Their marriages to [[Nicholas I Treutel|Nicholas Treutel]] and Andrew Garai, respectively, have prompted the rise of the [[Treutel family|Treutel]] kinship and the Palatinal branch of the [[Garai family]]. Ladislaus Nevnai handed over his estate of Nevna to his son-in-law Nicholas Treutel in 1324.{{sfn|Engel|1996|p=376}} It is presumable, he died shortly thereafter without male descendants, ending the Nevnai family line after two generations.Engel: ''Genealógia'' (Genus Péc 1. Zala branch) George's younger brother was Mark I, who appeared in contemporary documents in the period between 1240 and 1245. Alongside two other local nobles, he unsuccessfully filed a lawsuit for the ownership of some portions of Kajár (present-day Kajárpéc) in 1240; Béla IV ruled in favor of the [[Bakonybél Abbey]], referring to [[Ladislaus I of Hungary|St. Ladislaus]]' royal charters from the late 11th century.{{sfn|Vikár|1995}} He had five sons; [[Gregory Péc|Gregory]] was one of the military leaders of the Bulgarian campaign in 1266.{{sfn|Zsoldos|2007|p=98}} He was Ban of [[Braničevo (region)|Barancs]] and [[Kučevo|Kucsó]] in 1272–73,{{sfn|Zsoldos|2011|pp=51–52}} then [[Judge royal]] in 1288.{{sfn|Markó|2006|p=289}} It is plausible that he built the castle of Szentgyörgy in order to protect his landholdings against the [[Kőszegi family]]. However they besieged and captured the fort from Gregory's only son Joachim around 1315.{{sfn|Engel|1996|p=426}} Through his only son Stephen, Joachim was the forefather of the illustrious [[Marcali family]], which became prominent in the 15th century. The family died out in 1487.Engel: ''Genealógia'' (Genus Péc 2. Marcali branch) Mark I's second son Mark II (fl. 1275) remained insignificant member of the clan. His granddaughters' [[Daughters' quarter|filial quarter]] was divided between his brothers' surviving branches in 1349. The third son, [[Apor Péc|Apor]] was considered an influential baron at the turn of the 13th and 14th centuries, during the era of Interregnum. He had no descendants.{{sfn|Markó|2006|p=247}} Stephen I was the ancestor of the Berzencei (or Musinai) family and its cadet branches, the Lorántfis and Sándorfis.Engel: ''Genealógia'' (Genus Péc 3. Berzencei [Musinai] branch) [[Lucas III Péc|Lucas III]] served as ''[[ispán]]'' of [[Zala County (former)|Zala County]] from 1289 to 1291 and in 1298. He and his brother Apor besieged and captured Tátika Castle (located near [[Zalaszántó]]), which belonged to the property of the [[Diocese of Veszprém]].{{sfn|Engel|1996|p=441}} Thereafter, Lucas and his offspring were sometimes called with the title "of Tátika".Engel: ''Genealógia'' (Genus Péc 4. Szentgyörgyi branch) However the castle was lost to the [[Kőszegi family]] by 1314, when [[Andrew Kőszegi]] owned the fort.{{sfn|Engel|1996|p=441}} Lucas had five sons; one of them [[Apor Szentgyörgyi|Apor]] took the Szentgyörgyi surname, and became the first member of that short-lived family. *'''[[Lucas I Péc|Lucas I]]''', possibly [[Master of the cupbearers]] (1229–30) **[[George Péc|George]] (fl. 1232–56), ''[[ispán]]'' of [[Zala County (former)|Zala County]] (1243–44) ***'''[[Denis Péc|Denis]]''' (fl. 1256–85; d. before 1288), [[Palatine of Hungary]] (1273–74, 1277–78, 1283–84) ****[[John Péc|John]] (fl. 1292–1321; d. before 1327), ''[[ispán]]'' of [[Veszprém County (former)|Veszprém County]] (1295) ****''a daughter'' ∞ [[Stephen Hahót]] ***Serfesd '''Nevnai''' ****[[Ladislaus Nevnai]] (fl. 1284–1324) ∞ Yolanda Kórógyi *****Catherine (fl. 1324) ∞ [[Nicholas I Treutel|Nicholas Treutel]] *****''a daughter'' ∞ Andrew Garai ***Peter '''Ludbregi''' (fl. 1278) ****[[Nicholas Ludbregi]] (fl. 1317–57†) ∞ Tetis Bednyai **Mark I (fl. 1240–45) ***'''[[Gregory Péc|Gregory]]''' (fl. 1266–96 or 1309), [[Judge royal]] (1288) ****Joachim (fl. 1311–21), ancestor of the '''Marcali''' family ***Mark II (fl. 1275) ****Roland *****''daughters'' (fl. 1341) ***'''[[Apor Péc|Apor]]''' (fl. 1280–1307†), [[Palatine of Hungary]] (1298–99, 1304–07) ***Stephen I ("Lég"; fl. 1289–96), ancestor of the '''Berzencei''' family ***[[Lucas III Péc|Lucas III]] (also Lucas of Tátika; fl. 1289–98), ''[[ispán]]'' of [[Zala County (former)|Zala County]] (1289–91, 1298) ****Desiderius (fl. 1311–60) ****[[Apor Szentgyörgyi|Apor '''Szentgyörgyi''']] (fl. 1341–60) ****Stephen II (fl. 1341–53) ****Egyed (fl. 1341–53) ****Nicholas (fl. 1341–53) **Lucas II (also Lucas the Great) ***Ladislaus '''Kustáni''' (fl. 1274) ***Benedict '''Szőlősi''' (fl. 1274) ***''Lucas IV (?)'', see '''''Ibrányi''''' branch below ===Apponyi branch=== *Ivanka (fl. 1250) **Aladar (1294†), first member of the '''Őri''' (then '''Apponyi''') family **Ladislaus (also Ladislaus of Hrussó; fl. 1295–1317), castellan of [[Prievidza|Privigye]] (today Prievidza, [[Slovakia]]; 1308) ** Peter I (fl. 1295) *** Michael (fl. 1317–26) *** Stephen (fl. 1317–26) *** Peter II (fl. 1323–24) ** John (fl. 1295–1333) ===Ibrányi branch=== {{further|Ibrányi family}} ==References== {{reflist|20em}} ==Sources== {{Refbegin}} * {{cite book |last=Árvai |first=Tünde |editor1-last=Fedeles |editor1-first=Tamás |editor2-last=Font |editor2-first=Márta |editor3-last=Kiss |editor3-first=Gergely | title=Kor-Szak-Határ |publisher=Pécsi Tudományegyetem |year=2013 |pages=103–118 |chapter=A házasságok szerepe a Garaiak hatalmi törekvéseiben [The role of marriages in the Garais' attempts to rise] |language=hu |isbn=978-963-642-518-0 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Engel |first=Pál |authorlink=Pál Engel |year=1996 |title=Magyarország világi archontológiája, 1301–1457, I. ''[Secular Archontology of Hungary, 1301–1457, Volume I]'' |publisher=História, MTA Történettudományi Intézete |isbn=963-8312-44-0 |language=hu |ref=harv}} * {{cite journal |last=Kádár |first=Tamás |title=Egy figyelemre méltó Dráva vidéki főúr a 13. század második feléből: Péc nembeli György fia Dénes nádor és országbíró közéleti pályája [''A Remarkable Lord from the Dráva Region in the Second Half of the 13th Century: The Public Career of Palatine and Judge Royal Denis, son of George from the Clan Péc''] |journal=Somogy Megye Múltjából |volume=45–46 |issue= |pages=5–19 |year=2018 |language=hu |issn=1419-8010 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Karácsonyi |first=János |title=A magyar nemzetségek a XIV. század közepéig. II. kötet ''[The Hungarian genera until the middle of the 14th century, Vol. 2]'' |publisher=[[Hungarian Academy of Sciences]] |year=1901 |ref=harv|language=hu}} * {{cite book |last=Markó |first=László |year=2006 |title=A magyar állam főméltóságai Szent Istvántól napjainkig: Életrajzi Lexikon ''[Great Officers of State in Hungary from King Saint Stephen to Our Days: A Biographical Encyclopedia]'' |publisher=Helikon Kiadó |isbn=963-208-970-7 |ref=harv|language=hu}} * {{cite journal |last=Vikár |first=Tibor |title=Beszélő múlt: A Péc nemzetség története [''Talkative Past: The History of the Péc Clan''] |journal=Kispad |volume=5 |issue=3 |pages= |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103022604/http://kajarpec.hu/bemutatkozas/tortenet/beszelo-mult-a-pec-nemzetseg-toertenete |year=1995 |language=hu |issn= |ref=harv}} * {{Cite book |last=Zsoldos |first=Attila |year=2007 |title=Családi ügy: IV. {{Infobox Radio station |name = |image = |city = |area = [[Sudan]] |branding = |slogan =Independent news from the heart of Darfur and Sudan |frequency =0430-0500 UTC: 7315 kHz + 15550 kHz 1530-1600 UTC: 13800 kHz + 15550 kHz |translator = |repeater = |airdate = |format = |language = [[Sudanese Arabic]] (Former languages: [[Darfur|Darfuri Arabic]], [[Fur people|Fur]], [[Masalit language|Masalit]], [[Zaghawa language|Zaghawa]]) |power = |erp = |haat = |class = |facility_id = |coordinates = |callsign_meaning = |former_callsigns =Radio Darfur |former_frequencies = |affiliations = |owner = [https://www.freepressunlimited.org/en Free Press Unlimited] |licensee = |sister_stations = |webcast = [https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/broadcasts dabangasudan.org/en/broadcasts] |website = [https://www.dabangasudan.org/en dabangasudan.org] |}}'''Radio Dabanga''' ([[Arabic]]: راديو دبنقا) is a shortwave [[Radio broadcasting|radio station]] which serves [[Sudan]] with daily reports on the latest political, economic and social information, including health issues and social programs such as ''[https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/radio-program-highlight-reuniting-loved-ones Lost and Found]''. The shortwave radio has been broadcasting since December 1, 2008. Current broadcasts last for a total of one hour each day.
While Radio Dabanga only broadcast on shortwave radio for the first few years, the station now has several channels. The editors have innovated and experimented in the sphere of new media, often at the request of their listeners. These include Satellite TV, Facebook, WhatsApp, and SoundCloud. Depending on the medium, Radio Dabanga produces news in [[Sudanese Arabic]] and/or [[English language|English]].
Shortwave radio remains the mainstay of the radio station; one quarter of all Sudanese people are illiterate<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://uis.unesco.org/country/SD|title=Sudan|website=uis.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2018-09-05}}</ref>, a number that is relatively higher in Sudan’s remote areas and camps for displaced people. Many people here have no lifeline to the outside world other than telephone and radio, so it is Radio Dabanga’s mission to provide this.
==Broadcasting media==
=== Radio ===
Radio broadcasting is split into the [https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/broadcasts/broadcast/morning-news-21-august Morning News] and [https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/broadcasts/broadcast/evening-news-20-august-8 Evening News]. The morning news is broadcast from 0430 to 0500 UTC, at a frequency of 7315 and 15550 kHz and evening news is broadcast from 1530 to 1600 UTC, at a frequency of 13800 and 15550 kHz. This means that broadcasts reach Sudan between 07.30 and 08.00 in the morning and between 18:30 and 19:00 in the evening.
Besides the news bulletin, one program is broadcast every day. Editors pick which program is most suitable depending on the news of the day.
Current programs:
* ''[https://soundcloud.com/radio-dabanga/22-8-2018a-2 Talk of the Day]'' * ''[https://soundcloud.com/radio-dabanga/9-8-2018a-1 From the Camps]'' * ''[https://soundcloud.com/radio-dabanga/31-7-2018a-1 People’s Voice]'' * ''[https://soundcloud.com/radio-dabanga/22-8-2018a-1 Special Guest]'' * ''[https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/milafaat-detail-en/milafaat-sudania-عبدالله-عبداللطيف-مهدى-اسماعيل Milafaat Sudania]'' * ''[https://soundcloud.com/radio-dabanga/3-7-2018a-2 Health Advice]'' * ''[https://soundcloud.com/radio-dabanga/27-4-2018a-1 Plain Speaking]''
Other programs include ''[https://soundcloud.com/radio-dabanga/12-9-2019a-3 Lost and Found], Hababkum Darfur'' ("We Greet Darfur"), ''[https://soundcloud.com/radio-dabanga/26-6-2018a-1 Melodies from Darfur], [https://soundcloud.com/radio-dabanga/22-8-2018a Sudan Files],'' and ''Press Review. Lost and Found'' is a program which aims to reunite loved ones who have lost contact with each other when fleeing conflict, while ''Hababkum Darfur'' allows callers to send greetings across the airwaves to listeners in other places. Occasionally, drama programs are also broadcast over Radio Dabanga.
''[https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/radio-programme-highlight-we-empowered-people-to-claim-their-rights Fi Al Mizan]'' ("On the Scale") was a justice program co-produced by Radio Dabanga and the [[Institute for War and Peace Reporting]]. It focused on local and international justice issues.
Initially, in 2008 Radio Dabanga was broadcast for one hour per day. This increased to three hours per day, but because of the high cost of shortwave Dabanga went back to the original one hour per day; half an hour in the morning and half an hour in the afternoon.
Broadcasts are made in Sudanese Arabic. In the past, broadcasts also featured news in Darfuri Arabic, [[Fur language|Fur]], [[Masalit language|Masalit]] and [[Zaghawa language|Zaghawa]].
=== Television ===
Radio Dabanga has been broadcasting its TV satellite channel on Eutelsat since the 18<sup>th</sup> February 2018<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://allafrica.com/stories/201802190646.html|title=Sudan: Announcement - Dabanga Sudan Satellite Frequency Change|date=2018-02-19|work=Radio Dabanga (Amsterdam)|access-date=2018-09-05}}</ref> on frequency 11354 GHz. The TV Satellite broadcasts the latest radio programs 24 hours per day, showing the latest headlines of Radio Dabanga in text on-screen.
=== Online ===
Radio programs which are broadcast via shortwave radio and satellite TV are also [https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/broadcasts uploaded on Radio Dabanga’s website] and [https://www.facebook.com/راديو-دبنقا-السودان-1408025102826509/?ref=hl Facebook page]. On 21 August 2018, Radio Dabanga had uploaded a total of 1,848 broadcasts to its [https://soundcloud.com/radio-dabanga SoundCloud channel].
Radio Dabanga also produces news articles in Arabic which are published on the [https://www.dabangasudan.org/ar Arabic website], social media and WhatsApp groups.
Arabic news is often translated and reworked to suit an international audience on the English language part of the website and social media platforms.
==Reporting== Radio Dabanga reports in exile from Amsterdam. Until 2012 the editorial team operated out of facilities at [[Radio Netherlands Worldwide]], a public radio and television network based in the city of [[Hilversum]]. Since then the radio station has operated from the offices of Free Press Unlimited in Amsterdam<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.freepressunlimited.org/en/projects/radio-dabanga-radio-for-life|title=Radio Dabanga: Radio for Life|website=www.freepressunlimited.org|language=en|access-date=2018-09-05}}</ref>.
Before 2013, Radio Dabanga's main focus was conflict areas such as Darfur and the Blue Nile, producing independent news and relevant information for people of Darfur, including [[Internally displaced person|internally displaced persons]] and [[refugees]]. Since then the station increasingly shifted to being a reliable source of information for people in all parts of Sudan, covering a wide range of events and issues.
The [[editor-in-chief]] is [https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/makers-of-dabanga-the-story-of-kamal-elsadig Kamal Elsadig], overseeing a small group of reporters who work at the central desk in Amsterdam. The radio station receives news from people in the field. These stringers get in contact with the team with information about specific events, which the team then uses to verify and compile news.
Audience participation is a significant source of information as listeners call the radio studios with their own stories and tips. Increasingly, the editors use WhatsApp as a tool to receive, verify and publish news from interested individuals and specialist groups such as medics and civil servants in Sudan<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.humanityx.nl/projects/chatbot-radio-dabanga-free-press-unlimited/|title=Chatbot : Radio Dabanga (Free Press Unlimited) — HumanityX|date=2018-05-15|work=HumanityX|access-date=2018-09-05|language=en-GB}}</ref>.
== Audience == Radio Dabanga radio broadcasts reach 2.3 individual listeners per day (the population of Sudan is around 40 million) according to a listener survey conducted in 2009<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.balancingact-africa.com/news/broadcast-en/15262/sudan-short-wave-radio-still-going-strong-in-darfur-says-listeners-survey|title=Sudan: Short-wave radio still going strong in Darfur, says listeners survey {{!}} Balancing Act - Africa|last=dijit.net|website=www.balancingact-africa.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-05}}</ref>; the survey was held among 1,582 respondents over the age of 18 in cities, towns, and Darfur’s refugee camps. The Satellite TV channel is watched by an average of 1 million people per day in Greater Khartoum. Overall, the 2009 survey and spot checks in Khartoum revealed that Radio Dabanga reaches 6.5 million people per week via shortwave radio and satellite TV.
More information about the online audience of Radio Dabanga is presented in an [https://www.dabangasudan.org/factsheet/ infographic] on their website.
==Supporters== Radio Dabanga is conceived, operated and facilitated by the Dutch NGO Free Press Unlimited in the [[Netherlands]].
Radio Dabanga was founded 2008 by a coalition of Sudanese journalists, a number of international NGOs and the movers behind the Dutch campaign ‘Tot Zover Darfur’, including [https://www.vluchteling.nl Stichting Vluchteling], [https://www.paxforpeace.nl Pax for Peace] and [https://www.doen.nl Stichting Doen].
== Controversies associated with Radio Dabanga == While Radio Dabanga has a large audience in Sudan, the organization has been criticized by the Sudanese government in the past. The station has survived a number of government efforts to take TV Satellite and shortwave radio broadcasts off-air, including attempts at jamming and prosecution of reporters.
=== Television blocking ===
Radio Dabanga’s TV satellite channel was first set up in 2013 with Arabsat. After being taken down by the company in 2015 due to requests by the Sudanese government, Radio Dabanga began broadcasting with Nilesat instead<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.freepressunlimited.org/en/blog/radio-dabanga-censored-by-sudan-even-in-outer-space|title=Radio Dabanga censored by Sudan even in outer space|website=www.freepressunlimited.org|language=en|access-date=2018-09-05}}</ref>. At the time, Arabsat stated that “Radio Dabanga is considered an enemy of the Sudanese government, it’s not about a few controversial news items but about the whole station.”
Radio Dabanga’s channel was taken down from Nilesat in February 2018 due to a new request from the Sudanese government<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article64768|title=Egypt's Nilesat stops Radio Dabanga satellite broadcasts - Sudan Tribune: Plural news and views on Sudan|website=www.sudantribune.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-05}}</ref>. Faisal El Bagir of the network of <nowiki>[[Journalists for Human Rights]]</nowiki> stated at the time: “This measure illustrates that the regime does not tolerate independent opinions and voices, especially when it comes to the voices of those who would otherwise never be heard.”
Radio Dabanga now broadcasts via Eutelsat, a Paris-based broadcasting company.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official|http://www.radiodabanga.org/ }}
{{coord missing|Sudan}}

{{Infobox diocese |jurisdiction = Diocese |name = Kangding |local = 天主教康定教区 |latin = Dioecesis Camtimensis |country = {{flag|China}} |metropolitan = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chongqing|Chongqing]] |province = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chongqing|Chongqing]] |rite = [[Latin Rite]] |cathedral = Sacred Heart of Jesus Cathedral in [[Kangding]] |cocathedral = |area_km2 = 160,000 |population = 4,000,000 |population_as_of = 1950 |catholics = 5,870 |catholics_percent= 0.1 |pope = {{Incumbent pope}} |bishop = [[Sede Vacante]] |metro_archbishop = [[Sede Vacante]] |coadjutor = |auxiliary_bishops= }} The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Kangding/ Kanting''' ({{lang-la|Camtimen(sis)}}, {{zh|康定}}) is a Latin [[diocese]] in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of the Metropolitan of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chongqing|Chongqing]] in western China, but still dependent on the Roman missionary Congregation [[propaganda Fide]].
Its episcopal see is located in the city of [[Kangding]], know to the Tibetan as Dartsedo. It is vacant since 1962.
== History == * Established on March 27, 1846 as '''[[Apostolic Vicariate]] of [[Lhasa|Lhassa]]''' 拉薩 (after its [[Tibet|Tibetan]] see), on territory split off from the then [[Apostolic Vicariate of Szechwan]] 四川 * Renamed on July 28, 1868 as '''Apostolic Vicariate of [[Tibet]]''' 西藏 * Renamed on December 3, 1924 as '''Apostolic Vicariate of Dajianlu''' 打箭爐 * Lost territory on 15 December 1929 to establish the then [[Mission sui iuris of Sikkim]] (now diocese of Darjeeling) * Promoted on April 11, 1946 and renamed after its see as '''Diocese of Kangding''' 康定
== Ordinaries == (all [[Roman Rite]])
;'' Apostolic Vicars of Lhassa 拉薩 * [[Ignazio Persico]], [[Capuchin Franciscans]] (O.F.M. Cap.) (1856.12.19 – 1860), [[Titular Bishop]] of [[Gratianopolis (Mauretania Caesariensis)]] (1854.03.08 – 1870.03.11); later Bishop of [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Savannah|Savannah]] (USA) (1870.03.20 – 1874.06.20), Titular Bishop of [[Bolina]] (1874.06.23 – 1879.03.26) & [[Coadjutor Bishop]] of [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Aquino, Sora e Pontecorvo|Aquino, Sora e Pontecorvo]] (Italy) (1874.06.20 – 1879.03.26), succeeded as Bishop of Aquino, Sora e Pontecorvo (1879.03.26 – 1887.03.14), then [[Titular Archbishop]] of [[Tamiathis]] (1887.03.14 – 1893.01.16), Secretary of Sacred Congregation of the Propagation of the Faith (1891.06.13 – 1893.05.30), created [[Cardinal-Priest]] of [[S. Pietro in Vincoli]] (1893.01.19 – 1895.12.07), Prefect of the Roman [[Sacred Congregation of Indulgences and Sacred Relics]] (1893.05.30 – 1895.12.07) * [[Jacques-Léon Thomine-Desmazures]], [[Paris Foreign Missions Society]] (M.E.P.) (1857.02.17 – 1864.08.28), Titular Bishop of [[Synopolis]] (1856.04.04 – 1869.01.25)
;'' Apostolic Vicars of Tibet 西藏 * [[Joseph-Marie Chauveau]], M.E.P. (1864.09.09 – death 1877.12.21), Titular Bishop of [[Sebastopolis (Thrace)|Sebastopolis]] (1846.03.27 – 1877.12.21), formerly [[Coadjutor Apostolic Vicar]] of [[Coadjutor Apostolic Vicariate of Yunnan|Yunnan]] 雲南 (China) (1846.03.27 – 1864.09.09) * [[Félix Biet]], M.E.P. (1878.08.27 – death 1901.09.09), Titular Bishop of [[Diana (see)]] (1878.07.23 – 1901.09.09) * Pierre-Philippe Giraudeau, M.E.P. (1901.09.09 – 1924.12.03 ''see below''), Titular Bishop of [[Daphnusia]] (1897.02.15 – 1941.11.13), succeeding as former [[Coadjutor Vicar Apostolic]] of Tibet 西藏 (China) (1897.02.15 – 1901.09.09)
;'' Apostolic Vicars of Dajianlu 打箭爐 * [[Pierre-Philippe Giraudeau]], M.E.P. (''see above'' 1924.12.03 – retired 1936.08.09) * Pierre-Sylvain Valentin, M.E.P. (1936.08.06 – 1946.04.11 'see below''), Titular Bishop of [[Zeugma in Syria]] (1926.11.16 – 1946.04.11), succeeding as former Coadjutor Vicar Apostolic of Dajianlu 打箭爐 (1926.11.11 – 1936.08.06)
;''Suffragan Bishops of Kangding 康定 * [[Pierre-Sylvain Valentin]], [[M.E.P.]] (1946.04.11 – death 1962.01.07) * ''indefinite vacancy
== Sources and External links and References== {{Portal|Christianity in China}} * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/kang0.htm GCatholic.org] * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dkang.html Catholic Hierarchy]
